questions.question_text: What vSphere Distributed Switch security policy allows virtual machines to send frames with a MAC Address that is different from the one specified in the vmx file?

discussion.content:
Forged Transmits
Forged Transmits works as same as the MAC address changes policy. Only difference is it works on Outgoing traffic whereas MAC address changes works on Incoming traffic

Accept: If the Forged Transmits is set to Accept, Switch does not perform any security filtering and permits all the outbound frames from the virtual machine network adapter even if the source MAC address is different from the one saved in virtual machine configuration file (.VMX)

questions.question_text: In a Cross-vCenter implementation, where is the Universal Control Cluster deployed and configured?

choices.B: In each prepared NSX cluster associated with the Cross-vCenter implementation.
choices.A: In each vCenter instance associated with the Cross-vCenter implementation.
choices.C: In every vCenter instance associated with an NSX Manager.
choices.D: In the vCenter instance associated with the Primary NSX Manager.

discussion.content:
"Each cross-vCenter NSX environment has one universal controller cluster associated with the primary NSX Manager. Secondary NSX Managers do not have a controller cluster."

Answer is A:

1: Deploy NSX Manager
2: Register NSX Manager with vCenter Server
3: Deploy NSX Controllers
4: Prepare hosts

comments.content: This is related to question #51, NSX micro-segmentation only requires DFW, not VXLAN

discussion.content:
After reviewing my training notes, I'll go for C "Host preparation".
DFW is just another feature in NSX and you can implement DFW without implementing VXLAN. VXLAN being handled by "NXS Controller cluster".
There are two User world agents "vsfwd" and "netcpa". The vsfwd if for the DFW which communicates with the NSX Manager directly through the message bus while netcpa communicates with the NSX controller cluster via the TCP over SSL. NSX Controller Cluster communicates with NSX Manager via Internal REST APIs.

The answer is A, see page 14
https://www.vmware.com/content/dam/digitalmarketing/vmware/en/pdf/products/nsx/vmw-nsx-network-virtualization-design-guide.pdf

The official workflow for overaly networking with NSX-V is: Deploy NSX-V Manager -> Register with vCenter Server -> Deploy Controller Cluster -> Prepare Hosts -> Create Logical Stuff.
For real world DFW use-cases like Micro-Segmentation there is no Controll Cluster required thus only host preparation is needed: Deploy NSX-V Manager -> Register with vCenter Server -> Prepare Hosts for DFW.

This is a really bad question, I understand that host prep is required for DFW but having controllers deployed is a prerequisite of host prep. See below, copied from the link provided by NGA. 

Prerequisites
Register vCenter Server with NSX Manager and deploy NSX controllers.
C is the correct answer. Without host preparation VIBs are not installed and DFW will not function.

choices.C: Perform host preparation on the cluster

Is the micro-segmentation concept based on the VXLAN VNI separation? Or is it more of an NSX logical segmentation on top?
